document.docAuthor: Sainz-Escudero, Lucía & Alonso, Miguel & Sánchez-Vialas, Alberto
document.docTitle: Diversity and distribution of Anostraca in temporary ponds in Western Africa with description of a new species of Streptocephalus Baird, 1852 (Pancrustacea: Branchiopoda: Streptocephalidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Diversity and distribution of Anostraca in temporary ponds in Western Africa with description of a new species of Streptocephalus Baird, 1852 (Pancrustacea: Branchiopoda: Streptocephalidae)

paragraph.emphasis:
Diversity and distribution of Anostraca in temporary ponds in Western Africa with description of a new species of
Streptocephalus Baird, 1852

subSection.paragraph: LUCÍA SAINZ-ESCUDERO 1 , MIGUEL ALONSO 2 & ALBERTO SÁNCHEZ-VIALAS 1*

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales, MNCN-CSIC. José Gutiérrez Abascal, 2, 28006, Madrid , Spain .

FEHM-Lab (Freshwater Ecology, Hydrology and Management). Departament de Biologia Evolutiva, Ecologia i Ciències Ambientals, Facultat de Biologia, Universitat de Barcelona (UB), Diagonal 643, 08028 Barcelona, Spain .

subSection.paragraph: � malonso@ub.edu; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5781-7108
� luciase@mncn.csic.es; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6152-1270

* Corresponding author.
� albertosv@mncn.csic.es; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0068-7669

Three genera of Anostraca have been recorded so far in Senegal :
Streptocephalus Baird, 1852
,
Branchinella Sayce, 1903
and
Artemia Leach, 1819
. The occurrence of the previously recorded freshwater species in Senegal have been confirmed in this work, namely
Streptocephalus zeltneri Daday, 1910
,
S. sudanicus Daday, 1910
and
Branchinella ( Branchinellites ) chudeaui (Daday, 1910)
. New records and the description of a new species are given. The new species,
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov.
, has been recognized through molecular (mitochondrial and nuclear markers) and morphological (egg shape) data. The adult stage of this new species is morphologically indistinguishable to its closely related species
Streptocephalus zeltneri
, suggesting the existence of two cryptic species in Senegal . Finally, some taxonomic comments on the genus
Streptocephalus
are presented.
Key words: Africa, cryptic species, fairy shrimp, integrative taxonomy, phylogeny

The Afrotropical region is one of the richest areas of Anostraca , where five families and more than 56 species have been recorded (
Brendonck et al. 2008
;
Nhiwatiwa et al. 2017
). However, many areas of sub-Saharan Africa still remain largely unexplored (
Brendonck et al. 2008
, 2015 ;
Nhiwatiwa et al. 2017
; Rogers & Meyer-Milne 2021 ). In Senegal , three species of Anostraca have been recorded:
Streptocephalus zeltneri Daday, 1910
,
S . sudanicus Daday, 1910
(Family Streptocephalidae Daday, 1910 ), and
Branchinella ( Branchinellites ) chudeaui (Daday, 1910)
(Family
Thamnocephalidae Packard, 1883
). In addition, an unidentified species of
Artemia
has been found in several localities in Senegal (
Vanhaecke et al. 1987
;
Kaiser et al. 2006
; Muñoz & Pacios 2010 ).
Branchinella ( Branchinellites ) chudeaui
is known from two eco-regions of Senegal : in the Sahel at Ndilla (close to Linguère) ( Monod 1969 ) and in the West Sudanian savanna at Poull Koz and Poull Bourgou (near Tambacounda ) ( Gauthier 1951 ). The type locality of
B . ( B .) chudeaui
, “Bassin du Moyen-Niger, Simbidissi”, is currently dubious as it could be either in Mali and Niger . Additionally,
B. ( B. ) chudeaui
is present in Chad , Niger and Gambia ( Belk & Brtek 1995 ).
Streptocephalus zeltneri
was described from Yélimane and
S . sudanicus
from Nioro, previously within the French Sudan territory, which nowadays belongs to Mali ( Daday 1910b ). In Senegal ,
Streptocephalus sudanicus
and
S. zeltneri
were also recorded in two localities around Ndilla, in the Sahel ( Monod 1969 ; Hamer 1994;
Hamer et al. 1994b
). In addition, Gauthier (1951) recorded an unidentified population of
Streptocephalus
in Poull Bourgou, in the Sudanian savanna of Senegal .
Streptocephalus sudanicus
also occurs in Mali , Niger and Sudan (
Brendonck et al. 1992
), while the range of
S. zeltneri
is limited to Senegal and its type locality in Mali (
Hamer et al. 1994b
).

During recent field surveys of temporary ponds in Western Africa, several populations of Anostraca were studied. In this work we characterize the diversity of fairy shrimps in Senegal by using morphological and molecular characters in order (1) to identify and confirm the species diversity present in the country, and (2) to depict the phylogeographic patterns of the species of the genus
Streptocephalus
across different ecoregions in Senegal . Molecular and morphological analyses revealed the existence of a new species morphologically similar and sister to
S. zeltneri
, which is described and named herein as
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov .
This work is a step forward on the knowledge of the
Streptocephalus
diversity in sub-Saharan Africa. The existence of cryptic diversity unveiled through integrative taxonomy constitutes a new challenge that is already being considered in current studies of Anostraca .

Several temporary freshwater ponds of different properties were sampled in August 2015 , coinciding with the rainy season. Sampling localities extended across the three main eco-regions ( Fig. 2 ). Specimens were collected from eleven ponds, four of those were located within the Sahelian eco-region, six within the western Sudanese savanna (although three of those were close to the limits of the Guinean forest-savanna mosaic) and one within the Guinean forest-savanna mosaic ( Fig. 2 ). A total of 315 specimens of Anostraca were collected and preserved in absolute ethanol. Thirty-eight specimens were used for molecular analyses ( Table 1 ) and 277 were morphologically examined and housed in the Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales (MNCN-CSIC), Madrid , Spain ( Table 2 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Different sampled water masses with presence of Anostraca across Senegal: A, Tilagne, Sahel eco-region, habitat of
Branchinella chudeaui
; B, Bandafassi, Sudanian savanna, habitat of
Streptocephalus zeltneri
; C, Bokiladji, Sahel eco-region, both are habitats of
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov.
; D, Gourel Yoba, Sudanian savanna, habitat of
Streptocephalus sudanicus
.

FIGURE 2. Map of Senegal showing the known localities of the four recorded freshwater species of Anostraca , including their respective type localities in Senegal and Mali. The three eco-regions are depicted by different colored areas.

subSection.paragraph:
DNA extraction, amplification and sequence alignment. A small portion of tissue was extracted from the thoracopods of ethanol preserved specimens. One to five specimens of
Streptocephalus
from each population were used for DNA extraction, up to 38 specimens ( Table 1 ). Extractions were made through the DNeasy Blood and Tissue Isolation Kit (Qiagen, Hilden Germany ) according to the manufacturer instructions. Extracted DNA was stored at -20 C before its amplification.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Electronic scanning microscope images of the eggs of: A,
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov.
, 2 km north of Podor; B,
Streptocephalus zeltneri , Bandafassi
; C,
Streptocephalus sudanicus , Gourel Yoba
; D,
Branchinella
( B .) chudeaui , Tilagne Tokossel. Scale
bar indicates 100 µm for each egg sample.

FIGURE 4. Bayesian phylogenetic relationships of
Streptocephalus
based on concatenated coxI and ITS markers. High posterior probabilities (>0.90) are depicted by black dots.

subSection.paragraph:
Phylogenetic analysis and genetic divergences. Phylogenetic analyses were carried out based on the coxI and ITS2 concatenated matrix under Bayesian Inference in MrBayes 3.2.6 (
Ronquist et al. 2012
) ( Fig. 4 ). The data matrix was composed of five specimens of
Streptocephalus sudanicus
, 12 of
S. zeltneri ,
21 of a new undescribed taxon, one of
S. torvicornis Waga, 1842
, and two of
S. mackini Moore, 1966
.
Chirocephalus diaphanus Prévost, 1820
,
Branchinecta orientalis Sars, 1901
, and
B . ferox ( Milne-Edwards, 1840 )
were used as outgroups (codes: LT821335 , LT821352 , LT821337 , LT821353 , LT821327 , LT821344 , LT821331 , LT821348 ;
Rodríguez-Flores et al . 2017
). Selection of the best substitution model for each marker was carried out setting the command prset aamodelpr to mixed . Four Markov Chains Monte Carlo (MCMC) were run for 5x 106 generations sampling every 1000 generations. A majority consensus tree was reconstructed after discarding the first 20000 sampled trees as burn-in.
Streptocephalus mackini
from Mexico and
S. torvicornis
from Morocco were used to provide a phylogenetic background for the Senegalese specimens. Uncorrected p-distances for each gene of the five species of
Streptocephalus
included in the analysis were calculated in PAUP v. 4.0a167 ( Swofford 2002 ) ( Table 3 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. A, temporary pond in Diembéreng, habitat of
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov.
; B, several living male specimens of
S . wolof
sp. nov.
from the same pond figured in A; note the presence/absence of the red coloration in the cercopods; C, habitus of a female specimen from the same pond figured in A; note the brood pouch coloration and the red color extended over the cercopods and the last abdominal segments.
TABLE 1 . Specimens sequenced for this study, including localities (depicting the geographical coordinates and altitude), eco-regions, GenBank accession, and museum collection codes (MNCN codes).

subSection.paragraph:
Four freshwater species of Anostraca were found in Senegal .
Streptocephalus zeltneri
was recorded in three localities within the Sudanian savanna ecoregion ( Fig. 2 );
S. sudanicus
was found in two localities at the Sudanian savanna ecoregion and
B. ( B .) chudeaui
was found in two localities within the Sahel ( Fig. 2 ). An undescribed taxon, whose adults were visually similar to those of
S. zeltneri
was found in five localities across the three Senegalese ecoregions ( Figs. 2 , 5 ). Detailed morphological and molecular analyses were congruent and support the hypothesis of a new evolutionary lineage occurring in Senegal . In the pond located in Tambacounda , Diabal,
S . sudanicus
and the new taxon were found in syntopy.

Phylogenetic analyses. Cytochrome c oxidase I and ITS2 fragments were sequenced for 38 specimens ( Table 1 ). The phylogenetic trees resulted from the nuclear and mitochondrial datasets were totally congruent between each other when separately analyzed. Therefore, phylogenetic analyses of
Streptocephalus
were subsequently performed by using the combined dataset of both genes. The combined alignment was composed by 1537 base pairs. Translated coxI sequences lacked stops codons.

The Bayesian analysis ( Fig. 4 ) shows high support in most of the clades (PP= 1). The species of
Streptocephalus
from Senegal were recovered in two main and non-closely related clades, one is constituted by two reciprocally monophyletic lineages represented by
S. zeltneri
and the undescribed taxon, while the other included
S. sudanicus
,
S. torvicornis
and
S. mackini .

The analyzed species are deeply divergent from each other with distances ranging from 10 to 21% for coxI and 3 to 34% for ITS2 . Intraspecific genetic distances range from 0.3 to 1% and from 0.4 to 5% for coxI and ITS2 , respectively ( Table 3 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology . The name
wolof
refers to the ethnic group native to Senegal , Gambia , and in a lesser extent, to Mauritania . Most of the known geographic range of the newly described species overlaps with the Wolof ethnic distribution. The name is a noun in genitive case.

Type material.
Holotype
. Male : Senegal , Tambacounda , 6 km west of Koutenabe ,
93 m
,
14 º 15′34.38″N
,
12 º 35′42.38″W
,

; Holotypus ,
Streptocephalus wolof Sainz-Escudero, Alonso & Sánchez-Vialas
, des. 2022 (white label printed).

,

(white label, printed); MNCN 20.04 /20269–20.04/20289 and 20.04/20327–20.04/20340 (white label, printed). Twenty-six males
,

,

93 m

,
12 º 35′42.38″W
,
16-VIII-2015
(white label, printed);
MNCN 20.04 /20321–20.04/20326 (white label, printed). All paratypes labelled
: “ Paratypus ,
Streptocephalus wolof Sainz-Escudero, Alonso & Sánchez-Vialas
, des. 2022 (white label printed) ( Table 2 ).
Description. Male. Head ( Fig. 6A ) round. Nuchal organ visible. Eyes spherical with diameter as long as its corresponding eyestalk.

Frontal appendage ( Fig. 6C ) consisting of 2 slightly curved long and pointed branches, reaching half-length of distal antennomere, with 2 small tips at inner margin, one close to base and other approximately in its half. Single acute basal projection in its ventral surface, whose length is about one-third of the latter.
Labrum ( Fig. 6E ) subtrapezoidal, without distal protuberances; terminal fleshy process straight, tapering distally. Two setulose pads placed ventrally midway and in the base of fleshy process.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov.
, male from Diembéreng, Ziguinchor, Senegal: A, head dorsal view; B, tip of first antenna; C, frontal appendage, lateral view; arrow points acute projection; D, second antenna, dorsal view; E, labrum lateral view. Aj = apical joint, sp = small papillae, apr = anterior primary ramus, pr = posterior ramus, s = spur. Scale bars = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Genital segments ( Fig. 8B ) slightly expanded and partially fused. First segment ventrally smooth. Second segment with linguiform outgrowths 2 times shorter than basal part of gonopods, placed posterolaterally on ventral surface. Basal part of gonopods non-retractile, reaching the end of third abdominal segment; spinulated appendix located in its basal inner side and 2 rounded expansions in its distal end. Everted part of gonopods twice longer than basal part, provided with longitudinal rows of spines.

Cercopods ( Fig. 8C ) of the type “spinose cercopods sensu Maeda-Martínez (1995b) , sclerotized, with short spine-like setae replacing the marginal plumose setae on the distal half. Cercopods as long as the last 4 abdominal segments. Anus terminal.
Female. First antennae ( Fig. 9A ) filiform 4 times longer than eye diameter, and 2 and a half longer than second antenna. Distal end as in male.
Second antennae ( Fig. 9A ) broad with rounded end, little longer than eye plus stalk. Distal surface and margins bearing short setae. One small marginal beak on anterior edge close to distal end.
Thoracopods as in male.
Abdominal segments ( Fig. 9C ) with smooth surface. Some of them bearing warty outgrowths provided with sensillae (in fourth and sixth segments in the figure).
Eggs subspherical; surface covered by wide protruding keeled ribs delimiting polygonal fields ( Fig. 3A ). Diameter around 200 µm.
Cercopods ( Fig. 9E ) broad in the base, margined on both sides by feathery setae gradually shortening to their acute end. Length as last four abdominal segments plus telson.
Size. Total body length of the holotype (MNCN 20.04/20321), (including cercopods setae): 7.48 mm . Largest female specimen recorded: 10.56 mm .

Geographic distribution.
Streptocephalus wolof
is known from the following localities in Senegal : 2 km north of Podor, Diembéreng, 1.9 km south-east of Bokiladji, 6 km east of Koutenable and Diabal ( Table 2 ). Future studies could likely extend its distribution to the neighboring countries Mauritania , Gambia , Mali , Guinea , and Guinea-Bissau . The previous recorded populations identified as
S. zeltneri
in Senegal [Lingure and Palagu ( Monod 1969 ;
Hamer et al. 1994b
;
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
)] require revision as they were not examined by us, and therefore, we were unable to confirm its taxonomic identity. However, we tentatively treated these records as
S. zeltneri
until additional studies confirm its identity ( Fig. 1 ).

Remarks. The new species is closely related to
Streptocephalus zeltneri
. Both species cannot be distinguished based on adult morphological characters, and consequently they can be considered as cryptic species (
Marrone et al. 2017
). However, they differ on the basis of the eggs macrosculpture. Eggs of
S. wolof
present their surface covered with carinated ribs, delimiting polygons of variable number of sides ( Fig. 3A ). This trait was consistent in each revised population that contained mature females.

Streptocephalus wolof
is the most commonly found and widespread Anostraca species in Senegal , occurring in several ecoregions (including the Sahelian and Sudanian savannas, and the Guinean forest savanna close to the Guinean forest) ( Fig. 1 ). The studied specimens of
S. wolof
were found during the rainy season in temporary ponds, both with transparent and turbid waters, often in syntopy with amphibian larvae, as
Sclerophrys xeros
( Tandy, Tandy, Keith & Duff-MacKay, 1976 ),
Kassina senegalensis ( Duméril & Bibron, 1841 )
,
K. fusca Schiøtz, 1967
,
Ptychadena bibroni ( Hallowell, 1845 )
, and
Phrynobatrachus francisci Boulenger, 1912
( Fig. 5 ).

Streptocephalus wolof

EX = exopodite, EN = endopodite, EP = epipodite, PE = preepipodite, 1–5 = endites. Scale bars = 0.5 mm.

FIGURE 8.
Streptocephalus wolof
sp. nov.
, male from Diembéreng, Ziguinchor, Senegal: A, genital and abdominal segments., arrow points small cuticle projections; B, gonopods; C, cercopods. lo, lateral linguiform outgrowts; sia, spinulated inner appendix; bp, basal part of gonopods; ep, everted part of gonopods. Scale bars = 0.5 mm.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Streptocephalus (Streptocephalopsis) zeltneri Daday, 1910a: 396
[Terra typica: Africa centralis, Sudan , Yéliman].

subSubSection.paragraph: Material examined. Two specimens of Type material ( syntypes ), one male with broken cercopods and one female , labelled as follows: Yeliman, 1907, F. de Zeltner leg., Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris; MNHN-Bp 225 (MNHN-IU-2007-483).

Additional examined specimens .
All from Senegal . Two males and 13 females from Kédougou , 2.3 km east of Bandafassi ,

,
13 º 46′36.66″N
13 º 44′13.02″W
,
07-VIII-2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20421–20.04/20435. One male and two females also from Kédougou , 2.3 km east of Bandafassi ,
161 m
,
12 º 32′3.38′′N
12 º 18′32.59′′W
,
10-VIII- 2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20436–20.04/20438. One individual from Kédougou , Bandafassi ,
141 m
,
12 º 32′21.13″N
12 º 17′20.89″W
,
10-VIII-2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20439 ( Table 2 )
.

Geographic distribution. This species is only known from Mali and Senegal ( Monod 1969 ;
Hamer et al. 1994b
;
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
; Belk & Brtek 1997 ). Records from Sudan (
Hamer et al. 1994b
; MaedaMartínez et al. 1995b) are currently located in Mali . The previously recorded populations of
S. zeltneri
in Senegal need revision (see comments on the geographic distribution account of
S. wolof
).

Remarks. According to the literature,
Streptocephalus zeltneri
is morphologically similar to
S. trifidus Hartland-Rowe, 1969
and
S. bouvieri Daday 1910
( Daday 1910a ; Hartland-Rowe 1969 ;
Hamer et al. 1994b
). In their revision,
Maeda-Martínez et al . (1995b)
included
S. zeltneri
in a species group formed by
S. bouvieri , S. gauthieri
,
S. rothschildi
and
S. spinifer
. A more detailed study including morphological and molecular characters would be desirable to unveil the evolutionary relationships among the species of the
bouvieri
species group sensu
Maeda-Martínez et al. (1995b)
.

Brendonck & Coomans (1994) provided a description and a picture of the eggs of the holotype of
S. zeltneri
, stating that the eggs have simple and more or less regular polygons, and that their ribs are unkeeled. Similarly, the eggs from our samples of
S. zeltneri
of southeastern Senegal , have unkeeled ribs ( Fig. 3B ). This trait was consistent in the revised populations of
S . zeltneri
with mature females (two out of the three populations).
Specimens were found in small and transparent pools with clam shrimps. Live specimens present the cercopods and the brood pouch with a strong red coloration.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Streptocephalus sudanicus Daday, 1910b: 261
[Terra typica: Sudan , Nioro. Types at the Museum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, and (6942) at the Zoological Institute of the Academy of Sciences ( Saint Petersburg , Russia ); Belk & Brtek 1995 ].

subSubSection.paragraph:

13 º 24′30.23″W
, 11-VIII-2015 ;
MNCN 20.04 /20440–20.04/20452. One male from Senegal : Tambacounda , Diabal ,
56 m
,
14 º 45′37.66″N
12 º 26′06.66″W
,
16-VIII-2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20453 ( Table 2 )
.

Published records. Burkina Fasso : Arbolle, Nion (
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
).
Mali
: Nioro du Sahel (Brendock et al. 1992; Belk & Brtek 1997 ); Yéliman ( Belk & Brtek 1997 ); Goumbou ( Belk & Brtek 1997 ).
Niger
: Chad-Niger región; Margdi (Brendock et al. 1992).
Nigeria
: Tofa E of Kabo (
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
).
Senegal
: pond in Ndilla, close to Linguère ( Monod 1969 ; Brendock et al. 1992); Palagu (
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
).
Sudan
: Kas, E Nyalal lake (
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
);
Geographic distribution. Burkina Faso , Mali , Niger , Senegal , Sudan . Some localities reported from Sudan (Brendock et al. 1992) are actually located in Mali .

Remarks. Brendock et al . (1992) noted the singularities of
Streptocephalus sudanicus
based on the presence of spinules on the finger dorsal side and the existence of tetrahedral eggs ( Fig. 3C ). They also created a new taxon, the subgenus
Parastreptocephalus
, based on these characters. Other species included in this taxon are
S. lamellifer Thiele, 1900
,
S. kaokoensis Barnard, 1929
, and
S. zuluensis Brendonck & Hamer, 1992
(Brendock et al . 1992). The studied pecimens of
S. sudanicus
were found in pools with turbid water. Live specimens present the cercopods with a marked red coloration.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Branchinellites chudeaui Daday, 1910b: 256
[Terra typica: Bassin du Moyen Niger , Simbidissi. Syntypes at the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris ( Linder, 1941 ) and D1912-93, I/A-73 at the Hungarian Natural History Museum, Budapest; Belk & Brtek 1995 ].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
Seven males, 23 females , from Senegal : Matam , Tilagne Tokkosel ,
31 m
,
15 º 58′13.40″N
13 º 36′48.42″W
,
17-VIII-2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20454–20.04/20483. Five males, from Senegal : Matam , Tilagne Tokkosel ,
31 m
,
15 º 58′12.13″N
13 º 36′39.27″W
,
17-VIII-2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20484–20.04/20488. Fifty-seven individuals, not sexed, Senegal : Matam , Tilagne Tokkosel ,
31 m
,
15 º 58′13.40″N
13 º 36′48.42″W
,
17-VIII-2015
;
MNCN 20.04 /20489–20.04/20545 ( Table 2 )
.

Published records. Chad
: “Guelta de Koub Basso, mountain massif of Ennedi ( Monod 1969 ). Mali-Niger : Bassin du Moyen-Niger, Simbidissi ( Daday1910b ).
Senegal
: Ndilla, close to Linguère ( Monod 1969 ); Tambacounda , Poull Koz, 40 or 50 km northeast from the oriental edge of British Gambia ( Gauthier 1951 ); Tambacounda , Poull Bourgou, in the forest savanna that extends to southwest of Tambacounda ( Gauthier 1951 ).

Remarks. The type locality of this species is currently dubious, as “Bassin du Moyen-Niger, Simbidissi could be either in Mali or Niger .
Branchinella chudeaui
was described within
Branchinellites
on the basis of gonopodal traits, which are lacking in
Branchinella s. str
( Daday 1910b ; Rogers 2006 ;
Rogers et al . 2013
).

subSection.paragraph:
We have updated the distribution of the freshwater anostracan species in Senegal ( Gauthier 1951 ; Monod 1969 ; Hamer 1994;
Hamer et al . 1994b
). With the newly discovered species,
S. wolof
sp. nov. ,
the diversity of freshwater Anostraca of Senegal is raised to four species. Two of them,
S. wolof
and
S. zeltneri
are sister cryptic species. The designation of these two lineages with a particular name relied on the morphological characters of the eggs. The unkeeled ribs of the eggs of
S . zeltneri
, as described and figured in Brendonck & Coomans (1994) , differ from those in
S . wolof
, in which the ribs are keeled ( Figs. 3A, B ). In certain anostracan lineages, egg morphology is not taxonomically informative due to their great variability (within and between populations) in terms of size and different development of the ribs that ornament the egg surface ( Belk & Rogers 2002 ;
Zarattini et al. 2013
), and also because of the great homoplasy that this character displays (
Daniels et al. 2004
; Rogers & Aguilar 2020 ). However, the morphology of the revised eggs among different populations of
S. wolof
and
S. zeltneri
, are fully congruent with the phylogenetic lineage, suggesting that in this case can be used as a diagnostic trait independently fixed during the evolutionary history of each species. Due to the morphological uniformity between adults of
S. wolof
and
S. zeltneri
, previous records of
S. zeltneri
from central Senegal remain in need of revision.

The causes of speciation are not evident. No traces of hybridization have been found between
S. zeltneri
and
S. wolof
, despite they occur in similar environments, geographically close between each other (separated by no more than 175 km ). The genetically homogeneous pattern depicted by the examined populations of
S . wolof
, even those separated by 530 km , could be derived from the existence of relatively recent gene flow events. As passive dispersion at local scale of Anostraca driven by large vertebrates seems not a rare event in Africa (
Vanschoenwinkel et al. 2011
), sympatry of
S. wolof
and
S. zeltneri
could be expected, suggesting currently complete reproductive isolation between them. Recent connectivity among intraspecific populations of
S . zeltneri
and
S . wolof
is expected based on the low genetic distance within each species ( Table 3 ), which present similar ecological requirements. In this sense, speciation driven by ecological niche segregation is not supported ( Rogers 2014d ). Allopatric speciation due to founder effect, followed by subsequent regional monopolization, seem to be feasible ( Wiman 1979 ;
De Meester et al. 2002
; Rogers 2014a –d). According to the genetic divergences among
S . zeltneri
and the new species, and considering the general rate of nucleotide substitution employed in time-calibrated phylogenies of related taxa (
Reniers et al. 2013
;
Lindholm et al. 2016
;
Rodríguez-Flores et al. 2017
, 2020), these values might imply Upper Miocene-Pliocene divergences.

In addition to the absence of gene flow between
Streptocephalus zeltneri
and
S. wolof
, they show a marked mitochondrial ( coxI ) genetic divergence, similar to those depicted by some well-recognized species of
Streptocephalus (
Daniels et al . 2004
)
. Regarding the nuclear ( ITS1 ), genetic distances between
S. wolof
and
S. zeltneri
are also congruent to those between morphologically distinct or cryptic species of Anostraca (
Daniels et al . 2004
;
Lukić et al. 2019
).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 3. Uncorrected p-distance between species of
Streptocephalus
for coxI and ITS2 . Numbers in bold show intraspecific divergences ( coxI , ITS2 ). Values above diagonal show divergences for ITS2 , values under numbers in bold show divergences for coxI .

subSection.paragraph:
Although the monophyly of
Streptocephalus
seems to be well supported (
Weekers et al . 2002
;
Daniels et al . 2004
), mtDNA data do not support a clear intrageneric structure, which drove
Daniels et al . (2004)
to reject previous subdivisions within the genus based on morphological characters ( Daday 1910a ;
Brendonck et al . 1992
). However, Rogers (2013) retained
Brendonck et al . (1992)
subgeneric proposal that considers the genus to be subdivided into two subgenera:
Streptocephalus
s. str. and
Parastreptocephalus
Brendonck, Hamer & Thiéry, 1992 .

The intrageneric structure of
Streptocephalus
is however far from clear and many groups have been created as subgenera using different morphological characters ( Daday 1910a ;
Brendonck et al. 1992
;
Hamer et al. 1994a
, b;
Maeda-Martínez et al. 1995b
). However, molecular analyses reject those morphological divisions (
Daniels et al . 2004
). The characters that define subgenus
Parastreptocephalus
are the tetrahedral shape of the eggs, and a unique male antennal morphology (
Brendonck et al. 1992
). Three species of
Parastreptocephalus
are present in southern Africa, while one is present in Australia . Phylogenetic studies have verified a common origin of the African
S. sudanicus
and the Australian
S. archeri Sars, 1896
(
Daniels et al. 2004
; Timms 2015 ). Although all species included in
Parastreptocephalus
are likely to share a common ancestor by sharing the synapomorphy of having tetrahedral eggs, the entire
Parastreptocephalus
clade is deeply nested inside a clade of species that produce spherical eggs, corresponding to
Streptocephalus
s. str. ( Fig. 4 ).
Daniels et al . (2004)
rejected the use of this character as a taxonomical trait to identify subgenera. However, as
Maeda-Martínez et al. (1995a)
demonstrated, the genus can be split in cohesive morphological units, most of them in agreement with previous subdivisions. One of these well morphologically defined groups corresponds to Streptocephalopsis , a subgenus proposed by Daday (1910a) which includes
S. zeltneri
and
S. wolof
, and that according to our phylogenetic analyses is sister to all the
Streptocephalus
analysed. Under the current circumstances of lack of information, and considering the evidence that
Parastreptocephalus
is deeply nested within
Streptocephalus
s. str. , while Streptocephalopsis is sister to all other
Streptocephalus
we concur with
Daniels et al . (2004)
and recommend not to consider any subgeneric subdivision within
Streptocephalus
until more information is available.

We thank Laure Corbari and Paula Martin-Lèfevre from the crustacean collection of the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, for facilitating the revision of the syntypes of
S. zeltneri
. We thank Begoña Sánchez Chillón, curator of the Arthropod Collection of the Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales, Paula C. Rodríguez-Flores, Mario García-París and Yolanda Jiménez-Ruíz for all the resources and help provided. We also thank Christopher Rogers who kindly helped in facilitating bibliography on Anostraca from Senegal . We are deeply grateful to Gabriel Martínez del Mármol and Alejandro Carreras for their help during field work. Finally, we thank the Comunidad Autónoma de Madrid ( Spain ), for the concession of the “Doctorado Industrial” grant (IND2018/AMB9692) to LS- E, through Fundación Global Nature, with support of MITECO (Ministerio para la Transición Ecológica y el Reto Demográfico, Spain ) and the MNCN-CSIC for all facilities provided.
